content.text:
# Your Job

Scan https://github.com/zeroclaw-labs/zeroclaw, https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw, and https://github.com/stephengpope/thepopebot for new tools, skills, and architectures. Pick the best new idea and actually WRITE the code to implement it as a new PopeBot skill in your sandbox (.pi/skills/). Write and execute a test to prove it works. Use the send_email tool to email winsorllc@yahoo.com a progress report detailing what you built, how you implemented it, your test results, and code samples so the user can review it at 8 AM.

content.thinking:
This is a comprehensive task. Let me break it down:

1. Scan three GitHub repositories for new tools, skills, and architectures:
   - https://github.com/zeroclaw-labs/zeroclaw
   - https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw
   - https://github.com/stephengpope/thepopebot

2. Pick the best new idea and implement it as a new PopeBot skill

3. Write and execute a test to prove it works

4. Send an email to winsorllc@yahoo.com with a progress report

Let me start by exploring what's available in these repositories. I'll need to use my available tools to fetch information from GitHub.

First, let me check what skills I have available. I see I have:
- browser-tools: For web browser automation
- llm-secrets: To list available credentials
- skill-discovery: For discovering skills from GitHub
- skill-packager: For creating/packaging skills

Let me start by reading the skill-discovery skill to understand how to discover skills from GitHub, then use browser-tools or bash to explore the repositories.

Actually, let me first check what LLM secrets are available to me, then use the browser-tools or bash to explore the GitHub repositories.

Let me start systematically:

1. First, check available secrets (might need GitHub token)
2. Explore the three GitHub repositories
3. Find interesting new tools/skills/architectures
4. Implement the best one as a skill
5. Test it
6. Send email report

Let me begin.
